I had an epidural and havent had any problems besides a little tenderness in my back for a couple days after. the only bad thing was it took 2x to get it right.

I am on my fourth pregnancy and my very first child was all natural, no epidural and not by choice. I will nvr do that again!!! I hope to nvr go thru that again. Its your choice, but from experience, I would strongly suggest you get one. Ppl that have been against the epidural, ended up wantin one and were either lucky enough to still have time to get it or by the time the realized they wanted it, it was too late. I have had pain for a while after, in my back from the epidural, but everything comes with its territory. Good luck! :)
i Loved Out. No Problems With It.

I had one with my first child and I don't regret it at all. Why suffer when there's something to relieve you of the pain? I actually enjoyed delivery. Decide what is best for you, but keep an open mind either way. Do note though, that at a certain point it will be too late.

O didn't like it. It caused much back to hurt for several months after and carrying my newborn hurt badly. My son also had to go to special care and I was ready to see him but I had to wait for the epidural to wear off and through pitocin to finish off and then wait for the nurse to take me up. It was a long wait. I didn't want one in the first place, but having preeclampsia I was told I didn't have a choice. My blood pressure would raise really high with every contraction.
This time I hope I don't get pre e and I won't have the epidural. Ready to experience child birth. But I want a water or squatting birth I heard it's so much easier.

I didn't get any pain medication with my son. By the time I wanted something it would have been too late anyway. The "worst" part of labor is the very end, right before pushing. If you're up and moving, listening to your body and your baby, labor is usually quite manageable. I've had friends that went shopping for a few last minute things while they were in labor. Its all psychological. If you believe something is torture, its going to be torture. With a lifetime of conditioning about how labor is *so painful*, its no wonder many women freak out when it starts and multiply their pain by getting all bent out of shape.

question: I am doing some research on if getting an epidural is right for me when it is time for delivery. I am not for, or against it, but I am just curious to see some of the pros/cons about it and get some feedback to help me make a decision on if I really want/need it or not. I was told to sign the consent form to have it just in case, but I want to see if anyone had complications and what the reactions were.
title: Epidural, or not?
